Age: 51 Years Sex: Male DOB: 1970-12-03

Consulting Physicians

Discharge Follow Up
COVID-19 test on 2022-08-20 for procedure on 2022-08-23. VAD office will contac with schedule - 2022-08-20 11:00
Stop taking Eliquis on 2022-08-21 for procedure on 2022-08-23 - 2022-08-21 10:00

VT ablation scheduled with Dr. Gaitondae 12/23 and possible admission after procedure
Needs COVID test Monday 12/20.
Remind pt to stop Eliquis on 12/21.
HD MWF
Med change:
Stop carvedilol
Started Metoprolol XL 100 mg po daily
Started Mexiletine 150 mg po tid. (available in pt's pharmacy, confirmed)

Code Status
Start: 2022-08-12 22:31:00 EST, Full Code, Continuous Order

Patient is a 51 y/o M with ICM s/p BiVAICD (St. Jude; Dr. Gaitonde), Stage D/Class III HFrEF s/p HMIII (2021-10-24), CAD s/p PCI to RCA 2014, paroxysmal Afib, ESRD on HD MWF, recent RLE cellulitis and recent multiple admissions over the past few months. Pt. was feeling good at home with no complaints until he got up from bed today and received three ICD shocks. Patient had a similar episode last week as well for which he was also admitted, however, his medications were adjusted and he was doing well until today. Patient has not had any LVAD alarms, beeps recently. Denies abdominal pain, N/V/D. No recent illnesses, no fever or chills. Also reports compliance to his medications and denies any side effects.

Patient admitted following 3 shocks from AICD at 1600 on 12/12. Consulted EP, started on mexiletine 150mg tid, Coreg changed to metoprolol XL, scheduled for out patient VT ablation 2022-08-23. Pt to get COVID-19 test on 12/20. Instructed to stop Eliquis on 12/21.
Continue HD MEF, had one today, tolerated well. VAD stable, DLES dressing daily using VAD dressing kit.
Discharge plan has been discussed with patient, and he agrees to discharge at this time. Discharge instructions have been provided and patient verbalized his understanding. Discharge plan has been discussed with attending Dr. Pahwa and patient is stable for discharge home at this time.
During the course of his stay, the following issues were addressed:
VF with appropriate ICD discharge
-
Patient had an episode of 3 shocks around 1600 on 12/12.
- St. Jude Quadra Assura MP 3369-40Q CRT-D
- Followed by Dr. Gaitonde
- started
mexiletine 150mg tid
-Coreg switched to Metoprolol XL 100 mg daily
- Plan out patient VT ablation 2022-08-23

Patient: PARKER, Michael Daniel mrn:c485842938 fin:h3033850402
Age: 51 Years Sex: Male DOB: 1970-12-03

Chief Complaint:
VAD PT.  DEFIBRILLATOR FIRED X 3.  SINCE 1600.  ASYMPTOMATIC  WHEN IT FIRED.  CHEST PAIN 8/10 CURRENTLY.  HAD SAME 2 WEEKS AGO
Patient seen and examined. Tele Reviewed. Agree with above. Briefly, patient is a pleasant 51 yr old white male who follows with heart failure as well as myself. He was admitted recently admitted from 2022-08-05 to 2022-08-10 with appropriate ICD discharge for VT/VF. Amiodarone was increased to 200mg BID. After discharge he was feeling well until yesterday when he was shocked again from the ICD. He is very upset that he was shocked again. He is determined that if it shocks him again he will turn off all therapies and be ok with passing away. He states that no one should be shocked like he has been shocked. He currently is sitting in the chair and feels well. Device Interrogation reviewed - appropriate ICD Discharge.
No recurrent VA.
Negative except as stated above.

Neck : Supple. Carotid upstrokes are normal. There is evidence of jugular venous distention. Bruit noted.

Cardiovascular :
Regular. No r/m/g. PMI displaced with RV Heave.
GI: Benign, without hepatosplenomegaly, mass, or tenderness. The abdominal aorta is not palpably enlarged. No abdominal bruits are present. There is no hepatojugular reflux.
Extremities : No clubbing, cyanosis, nor edema present. The radial and ulnar pulses are 2+ bilaterally. There is no pulsus alternans.
Skin : Without evidence of xanthoma. Incision intact.
Musculoskeletal : No severe kyphoscoliosis.
Neurological : Alert and oriented X 3. Affect appropriate. Deficits noted.

Will need to make sure has underlying rhythm for scar mapping. COVID-19 testing appointment made for 12/20 at 8:30 am.
2. h/o ICD - implanted for primary prophylaxis in patient with ICM. Normal function. Device interrogation reviewed.
3. AFIB - permanent - s/p AVNode Ablation - paced rhythm. On AC.
Patient care discussed with Dr. Moore.
Okay for DC per EP once has Meritene.

Patient seen and examined. Tele Reviewed. Agree with above. Briefly, patient is a pleasant 51 yr old white male who follows with heart failure as well as myself. He was admitted recently admitted from 2022-08-05 to 2022-08-10 with appropriate ICD discharge for VT/VF. Amiodarone was increased to 200mg BID. After discharge he was feeling well until yesterday when he was shocked again from the ICD. He is very upset that he was shocked again. He is determined that if it shocks him again he will turn off all therapies and be ok with passing away. He states that no one should be shocked like he has been shocked. He currently is sitting in the chair and feels well. Device Interrogation reviewed - appropriate ICD Discharge.
No recurrent VA.
Review of Systems
Negative except as stated above.
Physical Exam
General : NAD
Eyes : There are no xanthelasma. PERRL, EOMI.
ENT : Oral mucosa without pallor or cyanosis.
Neck : Supple. Carotid upstrokes are normal. There is evidence of jugular venous distention. Bruit noted.
Respiratory : Clear.
Cardiovascular : Regular. No r/m/g. PMI displaced with RV Heave.
GI: Benign, without hepatosplenomegaly, mass, or tenderness. The abdominal aorta is not palpably enlarged. No abdominal bruits are present. There is no hepatojugular reflux.
Extremities : No clubbing, cyanosis, nor edema present. The radial and ulnar pulses are 2+ bilaterally. There is no pulsus alternans.
Skin : Without evidence of xanthoma. Incision intact.
Musculoskeletal : No severe kyphoscoliosis.
Neurological : Alert and oriented X 3. Affect appropriate. Deficits noted.
Labs/Tele Reviewed.
Assessment and Plan
A/P: 51 yo male with ICM with ICD with VT.
1. ICD Discharge - appropriate - on oral Amio that was recently increased from 200 mg daily to bid. Add Mexiletine. Not transplant candidate so very limited options - did discuss Ablation which he is interested - the earliest I can get Anesthesia with my schedule is Thursday 2022-08-23. Will need to make sure has underlying rhythm for scar mapping.
Risks and Benefits were fully explained to the patient.
2. h/o ICD - implanted for primary prophylaxis in patient with ICM. Normal function. Device interrogation reviewed.
3. AFIB - permanent - s/p AVNode Ablation - paced rhythm. On AC.
Patient care discussed with Dr. Moore.

Patient seen and examined. Tele Reviewed. Agree with above. Briefly, patient is a pleasant 51 yr old white male who follows with heart failure as well as myself. He was admitted recently admitted from 2022-08-05 to 2022-08-10 with appropriate ICD discharge for VT/VF. Amiodarone was increased to 200mg BID. After discharge he was feeling well until yesterday when he was shocked again from the ICD. He is very upset that he was shocked again. He is determined that if it shocks him again he will turn off all therapies and be ok with passing away. He states that no one should be shocked like he has been shocked. He currently is sitting in the chair and feels well. Device Interrogation reviewed - appropriate ICD Discharge.

--Ischemic Dilated Cardiomyopathy s/p St Jude BiV AICD upgrade 2019-12-11 (original AICD 2019-11-17) with AV nodal ablation, ICM with EF 10%, diagnosed 11/2018
--CAD
----LHC 3-2019: LM/LAD/LCX patent arteries and patent prox RCA stent
---s/p MI and PCI to RCA around 2014
----MI with stent 2012
-HTN

-COPD
-OSA

-Restless leg syndrome

Congestive heart failure.TECHNIQUE: CT of the abdomen and pelvis was performed with intravenous contrast. Isovue 370 100 mL was administered intravenously. Automated mA/kV exposure control was utilized and patient examination was performedin strict accordance with principles of ALARA.RADIATION AMOUNT: 2180.45 mGy-cm.COMPARISON: CT AP 2020-04-28 (report only; imaging unavailable).FINDINGS: Abdomen:Bilateral gynecomastia. Mild elevation right hemidiaphragm. Overlying mild volumeloss in the right middle lobe and right lower lobe. Lung bases are otherwiseclear. No pleural fluid. Left ventricular assist device is seen. ICD leads alsopresent, biventricular.Slight nodular contour of the liver possible early cirrhotic change. Probablediffuse hepatic steatosis. No focal hepatic mass. No CT evidence ofcholelithiasis. No biliary ductal dilatation. The spleen is mildly enlargedmeasuring 14 cm without mass. There are scattered calcifications in the spleenconsistent with old granulomatous disease. Mild bilateral cortical thinning ofboth kidneys without hydronephrosis, mass or calculus. The adrenal glands arenormal. No ureteral stones. Scattered subcentimeter retroperitoneal and small bowel mesenteric lymph nodes. Mildly enlarged porta hepatis lymph node 1.5 cm short axis, probably benign such asin the setting of chronic liver inflammation such as steatohepatitis. There is nofree air. Abdominal aorta is not aneurysmal.Pelvis:Minimal sliding hiatal hernia. The stomach is otherwise unremarkable. No bowelobstruction or ileus. Moderate colonic stool. There is no free fluid. Mildbilateral inguinal adenopathy, for example on the left on image 103 measures 2.5 x1.6 cm. Mild bladder wall thickening and indistinctness. Normal size prostate. Normal appendix. The iliac arteries are patent and the included femoral arteries are patent. Clipsare present in the right groin adjacent to the femoral artery withoutpseudoaneurysm. Skeleton:Hyperkyphosis of the lower thoracic spine with narrowing and partial calcified discspaces at several levels without significant vertebral body height loss. There ismultilevel lumbar degenerative disc disease especially L2-3 and there is moderatespinal canal narrowing at this level from disc osteophyte complex. There are noacute fractures. No suspicious bony lesions.IMPRESSION:1. Possible cystitis. Urinalysis correlation recommended.2. Hepatic steatosis. Question early cirrhotic change of the liver. Mildlyenlarged portacaval lymph node likely reactive.3. Mild splenomegaly.4. No bowel obstruction, free air or abscess. No acute pathology of the stomach,gallbladder, or pancreas identified. Minimal sliding hiatal hernia.5. Other chronic/ancillary findings as discussed.Signed by Jason Romesburg, DO

text.paragraph: No data available for this section

Heart Failure, Self Care
Heart failure is a serious condition. This sheet explains things you need to do to take care of yourself at home. To help you stay as healthy as possible, you may be asked to change your diet, take certain medicines, and make other changes in your life. Your doctor may also give you more specific instructions. If you have problems or questions, call your doctor.
What are the risks?
Having heart failure makes it more likely for you to have some problems. These problems can get worse if you do not take good care of yourself. Problems may include:
• Blood clotting problems. This may cause a stroke.
• Damage to the kidneys, liver, or lungs.
• Abnormal heart rhythms.
Supplies needed:
• Scale for weighing yourself.
• Blood pressure monitor.
• Notebook.
• Medicines.
How to care for yourself when you have heart failure
Medicines
Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your doctor. Take your medicines every day.
• Do not stop taking your medicine unless your doctor tells you to do so.
• Do not skip any medicines.
• Get your prescriptions refilled before you run out of medicine. This is important.
Eating and drinking
• Eat heart-healthy foods. Talk with a diet specialist (dietitian) to create an eating plan.
• Choose foods that:
◦ Have no trans fat.
◦ Are low in saturated fat and cholesterol.
• Choose healthy foods, such as:
◦ Fresh or frozen fruits and vegetables.
◦ Fish.
◦ Low-fat (lean) meats.
◦ Legumes, such as beans, peas, and lentils.
◦ Fat-free or low-fat dairy products.
◦ Whole-grain foods.
◦ High-fiber foods.
• Limit salt (sodium) if told by your doctor. Ask your diet specialist to tell you which seasonings are healthy for your heart.
• Cook in healthy ways instead of frying. Healthy ways of cooking include roasting, grilling, broiling, baking, poaching, steaming, and stir-frying.
• Limit how much fluid you drink, if told by your doctor.
Alcohol use
• Do not drink alcohol if:
◦ Your doctor tells you not to drink.
◦ Your heart was damaged by alcohol, or you have very bad heart failure.
◦ You are pregnant, may be pregnant, or are planning to become pregnant.
• If you drink alcohol:
◦ Limit how much you use to:
▪ 0–1 drink a day for women.
▪ 0–2 drinks a day for men.
◦ Be aware of how much alcohol is in your drink. In the U.S., one drink equals one 12 oz bottle of beer (355 mL), one 5 oz glass of wine (148 mL), or one 1½ oz glass of hard liquor (44 mL).
Lifestyle
• Do not use any products that contain nicotine or tobacco, such as cigarettes, e-cigarettes, and chewing tobacco. If you need help quitting, ask your doctor.
◦ Do not use nicotine gum or patches before talking to your doctor.
• Do not use illegal drugs.
• Lose weight if told by your doctor.
• Do physical activity if told by your doctor. Talk to your doctor before you begin an exercise if:
◦ You are an older adult.
◦ You have very bad heart failure.
• Learn to manage stress. If you need help, ask your doctor.
• Get rehab (rehabilitation) to help you stay independent and to help with your quality of life.
• Plan time to rest when you get tired.
Check weight and blood pressure
• Weigh yourself every day. This will help you to know if fluid is building up in your body.
◦ Weigh yourself every morning after you pee (urinate) and before you eat breakfast.
◦ Wear the same amount of clothing each time.
◦ Write down your daily weight. Give your record to your doctor.
• Check and write down your blood pressure as told by your doctor.
• Check your pulse as told by your doctor.
Dealing with very hot and very cold weather
• If it is very hot:
◦ Avoid activities that take a lot of energy.
◦ Use air conditioning or fans, or find a cooler place.
◦ Avoid caffeine and alcohol.
◦ Wear clothing that is loose-fitting, lightweight, and light-colored.
• If it is very cold:
◦ Avoid activities that take a lot of energy.
◦ Layer your clothes.
◦ Wear mittens or gloves, a hat, and a scarf when you go outside.
◦ Avoid alcohol.
Follow these instructions at home:
• Stay up to date with shots (vaccines). Get pneumococcal and flu (influenza) shots.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your doctor. This is important.
Contact a doctor if:
• You gain weight quickly.
• You have increasing shortness of breath.
• You cannot do your normal activities.
• You get tired easily.
• You cough a lot.
• You don't feel like eating or feel like you may vomit (nauseous).
• You become puffy (swell) in your hands, feet, ankles, or belly (abdomen).
• You cannot sleep well because it is hard to breathe.
• You feel like your heart is beating fast (palpitations).
• You get dizzy when you stand up.
Get help right away if:
• You have trouble breathing.
• You or someone else notices a change in your behavior, such as having trouble staying awake.
• You have chest pain or discomfort.
• You pass out (faint).
These symptoms may be an emergency. Do not wait to see if the symptoms will go away. Get medical help right away. Call your local emergency services (911 in the U.S.). Do not drive yourself to the hospital.
Summary
• Heart failure is a serious condition. To care for yourself, you may have to change your diet, take medicines, and make other lifestyle changes.
• Take your medicines every day. Do not stop taking them unless your doctor tells you to do so.
• Eat heart-healthy foods, such as fresh or frozen fruits and vegetables, fish, lean meats, legumes, fat-free or low-fat dairy products, and whole-grain or high-fiber foods.
• Ask your doctor if you can drink alcohol. You may have to stop alcohol use if you have very bad heart failure.
• Contact your doctor if you gain weight quickly or feel that your heart is beating too fast. Get help right away if you pass out, or have chest pain or trouble breathing.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
